newsitem.title: USA: Study shows smokers getting higher tar doses - WSJ.
newsitem.headline: Study shows smokers getting higher tar doses - WSJ.

text.p: A study sponsored by Massachusetts regulators shows that smokers receive much higher doses of tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide from cigarettes than tobacco companies disclose, the Wall Street Journal said Thursday.

The paper said the study is scheduled to be released today in hearings in Boston and could spur the Federal Trade Commission to change the way tobacco companies measure and disclose the figures they use in advertising.

Under the methods of the study, most of 10 brands tested -- including Merit 100s, Merit Ultra Lights and RJR Nabisco's Camel Filters and Camel Lights -- are yielding twice as much tar than shown in current tests, the report said.
Other brands included in the study are Carlton, made by B.A.T Industries, and Philip Morris' Marlboro, the report said.
